description: OSHA regulations, fall protection, scaffolding, trenching, PPE, hazard communication

questions.question: At what height must fall protection be provided for workers in general construction?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.501(b)(1), fall protection must be provided at 6 feet or more above a lower level in general construction. Different heights apply to specific situations.

questions.question: What are the three main types of fall protection systems?

options.text: Guardrails, safety nets, personal fall arrest systems

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502, the three conventional fall protection systems are guardrail systems, safety net systems, and personal fall arrest systems (PFAS).

questions.question: What is the required height for a top rail in a guardrail system?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(b)(1), guardrail top rails must be 42 inches high, plus or minus 3 inches, above the walking/working surface.

questions.question: What force must a guardrail top rail withstand?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(b)(3), guardrail top rails must withstand at least 200 pounds of force applied in any outward or downward direction.

questions.question: What is the maximum free fall distance permitted with a personal fall arrest system?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(d)(16), a personal fall arrest system must limit free fall to 6 feet or less and limit maximum arresting force to 1,800 pounds.

questions.question: What is the minimum tensile strength required for an anchor point in a personal fall arrest system?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(d)(15), anchorages for personal fall arrest systems must be capable of supporting at least 5,000 pounds per worker attached.

questions.question: After a fall arrest, what must be done with the personal fall arrest equipment?

options.text: Remove from service and inspect before reuse

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(d)(21), personal fall arrest systems and components subjected to impact loading must be immediately removed from service and not used again until inspected and determined to be undamaged.

questions.question: What is a warning line system?

options.text: Caution tape around the job site
A barrier erected to warn workers they are approaching an unprotected edge

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(f), a warning line system is a barrier erected on a roof to warn workers they are approaching an unprotected edge. It's used with other controls on low-slope roofs.

questions.question: How far from the roof edge must a warning line be erected?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(f)(1), warning lines must be erected not less than 6 feet from the roof edge.

questions.question: What is the role of a safety monitor?

options.text: To warn workers when they approach fall hazards

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.502(h), a safety monitor is a competent person who warns workers when they appear to be unaware of a fall hazard or are acting unsafely.

questions.question: Who must inspect scaffolds before each work shift?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.451(f)(3), scaffolds must be inspected by a competent person before each work shift and after any occurrence that could affect structural integrity.

questions.question: What is the maximum height-to-base ratio for a freestanding scaffold?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.451(c)(1), freestanding scaffolds must have a height-to-base width ratio of no more than 4:1 unless guyed, tied, or braced.

questions.question: What is the minimum width for a scaffold platform?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.451(b)(2), scaffold platforms must be at least 18 inches wide, unless the work area is too narrow for that width.

questions.question: What is the maximum gap permitted between scaffold planks and the structure being worked on?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.451(b)(3), the front edge of scaffold platforms must be no more than 14 inches from the face of the work, unless guardrails are used.

questions.question: At what height is fall protection required on scaffolds?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.451(g)(1), fall protection is required on scaffolds more than 10 feet above a lower level.

questions.question: What load must a scaffold platform be capable of supporting?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.451(a)(1), scaffolds must be capable of supporting at least 4 times the maximum intended load without failure.

questions.question: What must be done before moving a rolling scaffold?

options.text: Remove all workers, materials, and equipment from the platform

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.452(w)(6), workers must not ride on mobile scaffolds unless specific conditions are met, and loose materials must be secured before moving.

questions.question: What must happen to scaffold wheels when the scaffold is stationary?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.452(w)(2), scaffold casters and wheels must be locked when the scaffold is stationary to prevent unintended movement.

questions.question: How far above the landing surface must a ladder extend?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1053(b)(1), the side rails of a ladder must extend at least 3 feet above the upper landing surface.

questions.question: What is the proper angle for setting up a straight ladder?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1053(b)(5)(i), non-self-supporting ladders must be set at a 1:4 ratio - the base should be 1 foot out for every 4 feet of height.

questions.question: What is the minimum clear distance between ladder rungs?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1053(a)(3)(i), ladder rungs must be spaced uniformly, not less than 10 inches and not more than 14 inches apart.

questions.question: When climbing a ladder, a worker should maintain:
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1053(b)(20), workers must maintain three points of contact (two hands and one foot, or two feet and one hand) when climbing ladders.

questions.question: A defective ladder must be:

options.text: Reported at the end of the day

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1053(b)(16), defective ladders must be immediately marked as defective or tagged "Do Not Use" and withdrawn from service until repaired.

questions.question: At what depth must protective systems be used in excavations?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.652(a)(1), protective systems (sloping, shoring, or shielding) are required for excavations 5 feet or more in depth, unless the excavation is in stable rock.

questions.question: What are the three main types of protective systems for excavations?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.652, the three primary protective systems are sloping/benching, shoring (hydraulic, timber, etc.), and shielding (trench boxes).

questions.question: What is Type A soil?

options.text: Cohesive soil with unconfined compressive strength of 1.5 tsf or greater

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.652 Appendix A, Type A soil is the most stable, with unconfined compressive strength of 1.5 tons per square foot (tsf) or greater. Examples include clay and hardpan.

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable slope for Type C soil?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.652 Appendix B, Type C soil (the least stable) requires a maximum slope of 1-1/2:1 (1.5 horizontal to 1 vertical, or 34 degrees from horizontal).

questions.question: Who must classify soil and inspect excavations?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.651(k)(1), a competent person must inspect excavations daily before work begins, after rain, and as conditions change. They must also classify soil.

questions.question: How close to the edge of an excavation must spoil piles be kept?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.651(j)(2), spoil piles must be kept at least 2 feet from the edge of the excavation to prevent material from falling back in.

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for exits (ladders, ramps, stairs) in trenches?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.651(c)(2), means of egress (ladders, ramps, stairs) must be located so that no worker has to travel more than 25 feet laterally to reach one.

questions.question: What must be done before excavation work begins?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.651(b)(1), the estimated location of underground utilities must be determined before excavation begins by contacting utility companies or using call-before-you-dig services.

questions.question: What is a trench box (shield)?

options.text: A structure that protects workers from cave-ins

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.652(c), a trench shield (trench box) is a structure designed to withstand cave-in forces and protect workers inside the excavation.

questions.question: When is head protection required on construction sites?

options.text: When there is danger of head injury from falling objects

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.100(a), employees must wear protective helmets when there is possible danger of head injury from impact, falling objects, or electrical shock.

questions.question: What standard must construction hard hats meet?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.100(b), protective helmets must comply with ANSI Z89.1 (American National Standard for Industrial Head Protection).

questions.question: When is eye protection required?

options.text: When there is danger of eye injury from flying particles, chemicals, or radiation

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.102(a)(1), eye protection is required when exposed to hazards such as flying particles, molten metal, chemicals, gases, or harmful light radiation.

questions.question: What is the minimum shade number for welding with SMAW (stick welding) at 100-150 amps?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.102 Table E-2, shielded metal arc welding (SMAW) at 100-150 amps requires minimum shade 10 eye protection.

questions.question: Who is responsible for providing personal protective equipment?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.95(d), employers must provide required PPE at no cost to employees, with limited exceptions for safety footwear and prescription safety eyewear.

questions.question: When is hearing protection required?

options.text: When noise exposure reaches 85 dBA over an 8-hour TWA

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.52, hearing protection is required when employee noise exposure equals or exceeds an 8-hour time-weighted average of 85 decibels.

questions.question: What is the permissible noise exposure limit for an 8-hour workday?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.52 Table D-2, the permissible noise exposure for an 8-hour duration is 90 dBA. Higher levels are permitted for shorter durations.

questions.question: What type of gloves should NOT be used when working with rotating machinery?

options.text: Any loose-fitting gloves that can get caught

questions.explanation: Loose-fitting gloves can be caught by rotating machinery and pull the worker's hand into the equipment. Proper selection of PPE considers the hazard type.

questions.question: What is the purpose of an SDS (Safety Data Sheet)?

options.text: To provide hazard information about chemicals

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1910.1200, Safety Data Sheets provide comprehensive information about chemical hazards, safe handling, storage, emergency procedures, and protective measures.

questions.question: How many sections are in a GHS-compliant Safety Data Sheet?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1910.1200 Appendix D, GHS-compliant Safety Data Sheets have 16 standardized sections covering identification, hazards, composition, first aid, handling, exposure controls, and more.

questions.question: Where must Safety Data Sheets be kept?

options.text: Readily accessible to employees in the work area

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1910.1200(g)(8), employers must ensure SDSs are readily accessible to employees during their work shift. Electronic access is permitted if no barriers exist.

questions.question: What information must be on a chemical container label?

options.text: Product identifier, signal word, hazard statements, and precautionary statements

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1910.1200(f), labels must include product identifier, signal word (Danger or Warning), hazard statements, precautionary statements, pictograms, and supplier information.

questions.question: What does a skull and crossbones pictogram indicate?
questions.explanation: Per GHS hazard communication standards, the skull and crossbones pictogram indicates acute toxicity - the substance can be fatal or toxic if inhaled, ingested, or absorbed through skin.

questions.question: What is the minimum safe approach distance for qualified workers to energized 50kV lines?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.97 Table V-1, the minimum approach distance for 50kV is 10 feet. Distances increase with voltage level.

questions.question: What is GFCI protection?

options.text: Protection that detects ground faults and shuts off power

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.405(a)(2)(ii), a Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter detects current leakage to ground and disconnects power to prevent electrocution.

questions.question: What protection is required for all 120-volt, single-phase, 15- and 20-ampere receptacles on construction sites?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.405(a)(2)(ii), all 120V, single-phase, 15- and 20-amp receptacles on construction sites must have GFCI protection.

questions.question: What must be done before working on electrical equipment?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.417, circuits must be de-energized before work begins, and lockout/tagout procedures must be followed to prevent accidental energization.

questions.question: What color are equipment grounding conductors?

options.text: Green or green with yellow stripes

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.405(g)(2)(iii) and NEC, equipment grounding conductors must be identified by a continuous green color or green with yellow stripes.

questions.question: What class of fire involves ordinary combustibles like wood and paper?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.150, Class A fires involve ordinary combustibles such as wood, paper, cloth, and plastics.

questions.question: What class of fire involves flammable liquids?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.150, Class B fires involve flammable liquids, gases, and greases such as gasoline, oil, and solvents.

questions.question: What class of fire involves energized electrical equipment?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.150, Class C fires involve energized electrical equipment where the electrical non-conductivity of the extinguishing media is important.

questions.question: How far can the travel distance be to a fire extinguisher?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.150(c)(1)(ii), fire extinguishers must be located so that the travel distance is no more than 100 feet.

questions.question: How often must fire extinguishers be inspected?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.150(c)(1)(viii), portable fire extinguishers must be inspected periodically and maintained in operating condition. Monthly visual inspection is standard practice.

questions.question: What does PASS stand for when using a fire extinguisher?
questions.explanation: PASS is the standard method: Pull the pin, Aim at the base of the fire, Squeeze the handle, and Sweep from side to side.

questions.question: What defines a confined space?

options.text: A space large enough to enter with limited entry/exit and not designed for continuous occupancy

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1202, a confined space is large enough for a worker to enter and perform work, has limited or restricted means of entry/exit, and is not designed for continuous occupancy.

questions.question: What additional hazards make a confined space a permit-required confined space?

options.text: Atmospheric hazards, engulfment, entrapment, or other serious hazards

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1202, a permit-required confined space has hazardous atmosphere potential, engulfment hazard, configuration that could trap/asphyxiate, or other recognized serious safety hazards.

questions.question: What is the minimum oxygen level for a safe confined space atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1203, a hazardous atmosphere includes oxygen deficiency below 19.5% or oxygen enrichment above 23.5%.

questions.question: Who must be stationed outside a permit-required confined space during entry?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1209, an attendant must be stationed outside the permit space to monitor entrants, maintain communication, and summon rescue if needed.

questions.question: Who must inspect cranes before each shift?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1412(d), a competent person must inspect cranes before each shift for deficiencies and ensure required repairs are made.

questions.question: What is the minimum safe distance from power lines up to 50kV for crane operations?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1408, the minimum clearance distance for cranes operating near power lines up to 50kV is 10 feet.

questions.question: What must be done before lifting a load?

options.text: Determine the load weight and verify it's within the crane's rated capacity

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1417, the weight of the load must be determined and verified to be within the crane's rated capacity for the configuration and radius.

questions.question: What is the role of a signal person in crane operations?

options.text: To direct crane movement when the operator cannot see the load

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1419, a signal person is required when the point of operation is not visible to the operator, directing the crane's movement through standardized signals.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a load chart?

options.text: To show the crane's lifting capacity at various radii and configurations

questions.explanation: A load chart shows the crane's rated capacity at various boom lengths, radii, and configurations. It must be consulted before every lift.

questions.question: What is the minimum safety factor for wire rope slings?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.251, wire rope slings must have a design factor of 5:1, meaning the breaking strength is at least 5 times the rated capacity.

questions.question: When must slings be removed from service?

options.text: When damage such as broken wires, kinks, or corrosion is found
At the end of the project

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.251(c)(4), wire rope slings must be removed from service when damage such as broken wires, severe corrosion, kinking, or other defects are present.

questions.question: What happens to sling capacity as the sling angle decreases from vertical?
questions.explanation: As the sling angle from vertical decreases (becomes more horizontal), the stress on each leg increases and the rated capacity decreases significantly.

questions.question: What is an OSHA 'competent person'?

options.text: One capable of identifying hazards and authorized to take corrective action

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.32(f), a competent person is capable of identifying existing and predictable hazards and has authority to take prompt corrective measures.

questions.question: What is an OSHA 'qualified person'?

options.text: One who has demonstrated ability by education, training, or experience

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.32(m), a qualified person has demonstrated the ability to solve problems related to the subject matter by education, training, or experience.

questions.question: When must safety training be provided?

options.text: Before workers are exposed to hazards
At the end of the project

questions.explanation: Per OSHA requirements, employers must train workers to recognize hazards before they are exposed to them. Training must be in a language workers understand.

questions.question: What documentation is required for safety training?

options.text: Records showing who was trained, topics covered, and date

questions.explanation: Training records should document the employee's name, training date, topics covered, and trainer. This verifies compliance with training requirements.

questions.question: What is required regarding housekeeping on construction sites?

options.text: Keep work areas, passageways, and stairs clear of debris

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.25, work areas, passageways, stairs, and areas around buildings must be kept clear of debris and scrap. Materials must be stored safely.

questions.question: How must protruding nails in scrap lumber be handled?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.25(a), all scrap lumber with protruding nails must have the nails removed, bent, or otherwise covered to prevent puncture injuries.

questions.question: What is the maximum height for storing lumber?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.250(b)(1), lumber stacks must not exceed 20 feet in height when handled manually or 16 feet when using mechanical equipment.

questions.question: How must compressed gas cylinders be stored?

options.text: Upright and secured to prevent falling
Stacked on top of each other

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.350(a)(10), compressed gas cylinders must be stored upright and secured to prevent falling. Caps must be in place when not in use.

questions.question: What is the minimum separation between oxygen and fuel gas cylinders?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.350(a)(10), oxygen cylinders must be separated from fuel gas cylinders by at least 20 feet or by a 5-foot fire-resistant barrier.

questions.question: What is the required inspection for power tools?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.300(a), all hand and power tools must be maintained in safe condition. Workers should inspect tools before each use.

questions.question: What must be present on all power tools with exposed moving parts?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.300(b)(1), guards must be provided to protect workers from point of operation, nip points, rotating parts, flying chips, and sparks.

questions.question: What must be done with a power tool that is defective?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.300(a), defective tools must be removed from service and tagged "Do Not Use" or taken out of the work area.

questions.question: What is required when construction vehicles operate in reverse?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.601(b)(4), vehicles with an obstructed rear view must have backup alarms or an observer when backing.

questions.question: Are seatbelts required in construction vehicles?

options.text: Yes, when provided by the manufacturer

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.602(a)(2)(i), seatbelts must be installed and used in motor vehicles if the vehicle was equipped with ROPS and/or had a seatbelt installed by the manufacturer.

questions.question: What PPE is required when working with wet concrete?

options.text: Waterproof gloves, boots, and eye protection

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.702(a), workers must wear appropriate PPE when in contact with wet concrete including waterproof gloves, rubber boots, and eye protection due to alkaline burns.

questions.question: What hazard does silica dust from concrete cutting pose?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA's silica rule (1926.1153), crystalline silica dust from cutting, grinding, or drilling concrete can cause silicosis, lung cancer, and other respiratory diseases.

questions.question: What is the permissible exposure limit (PEL) for respirable crystalline silica?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1153, the PEL for respirable crystalline silica is 50 micrograms per cubic meter of air, averaged over an 8-hour shift.

questions.question: What must be done before starting demolition work?

options.text: Complete an engineering survey and disconnect utilities

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.850(a), an engineering survey must be made by a competent person before demolition starts, and all utilities must be shut off and capped.

questions.question: When removing floor sections during demolition, what protection must remain?

options.text: Floor openings must be protected with covers or guardrails

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.501, floor openings created during demolition must be guarded with covers or guardrails to prevent falls.

questions.question: What is the permissible exposure limit for lead in construction?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.62, the PEL for lead is 50 micrograms per cubic meter of air averaged over an 8-hour period. Action level is 30 g/m.

questions.question: What year was lead banned in residential paint?
questions.explanation: Lead-based paint was banned for residential use in 1978. Homes built before 1978 may contain lead paint, requiring specific precautions during renovation.

questions.question: What is the permissible exposure limit for asbestos?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1101, the PEL for asbestos is 0.1 fibers per cubic centimeter of air as an 8-hour TWA.

questions.question: What diseases can asbestos exposure cause?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.1101, asbestos exposure can cause asbestosis (lung scarring), lung cancer, and mesothelioma (cancer of the chest and abdominal lining).

questions.question: When is first aid coverage required on a construction site?

options.text: When a medical facility is not near or reasonably accessible

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.50(c), trained first aid providers must be available when a hospital, clinic, or infirmary is not reasonably accessible.

questions.question: What must be available for emergency washing of eyes or body?

options.text: Suitable facilities for quick drenching or flushing

questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1926.50(g), where employees may be exposed to corrosive materials, suitable facilities for quick drenching or flushing of eyes and body must be provided.

questions.question: What OSHA form is used to record workplace injuries and illnesses?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1904, the OSHA 300 Log is used to record work-related injuries and illnesses. The 300A Summary must be posted annually.

questions.question: When must a fatality be reported to OSHA?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA 1904.39, employers must report any work-related fatality within 8 hours. Hospitalizations, amputations, and eye losses must be reported within 24 hours.

questions.question: On a multi-employer construction site, who is responsible for safety?

options.text: Multiple employers may share responsibility depending on their role

questions.explanation: Per OSHA's multi-employer citation policy, creating, exposing, correcting, and controlling employers may all have responsibilities for hazards on multi-employer sites.

questions.question: What type of OSHA violation involves an immediate risk of death or serious harm?
questions.explanation: An imminent danger exists when there is reasonable certainty that a hazard exists that can cause death or serious physical harm immediately or before normal enforcement procedures.

questions.question: What are the maximum penalties for a willful OSHA violation?
questions.explanation: Per OSHA, willful violations can result in penalties up to $156,259 per violation (2023 amount, adjusted annually). Repeat violations have similar maximum penalties.

questions.question: Do workers have the right to refuse unsafe work?

options.text: Yes, under certain conditions when facing imminent danger

questions.explanation: Per OSHA, workers may refuse to do a job if they believe in good faith they face imminent danger, have asked the employer to correct the hazard, and normal enforcement would be too slow.

questions.question: What protection do workers have against retaliation for reporting safety concerns?

options.text: Whistleblower protection under Section 11(c) of the OSH Act

questions.explanation: Per OSHA Section 11(c), workers are protected from retaliation (firing, demotion, transfer) for exercising safety rights, reporting hazards, or participating in OSHA activities.
